Posts.Content: suz45 wrote: OK my first post here in ages. Im just trying to find a place to be comfortable to talk again on this board. So far Ive tried posting on a few threads but deleted them, Im just not that comfortable here yet. After all its been a while and I didnt plan on coming back . Life doesnt work the way we plan. So Im gonna just talk here for this post and see where it takes me. I figured once I had my tubes and ovaries removed last Sept I was done, went on an incredible vacation with dh in Nov. Life was finally returning to normal! Had my routine mammo & ultrasound in Feb. 09. they called me back for a MRI core biopsy,on my right (good) side. They never did it as as soon as I was in the mri machine they said not cancer just a very small cyst. My next set of appointments were set for  August 28 MRI and  Sept 10, 09 with my Oncologist. Great.. I was free and clear for 6 more months. Well the beginning of May I found a noticible lump on my right breast. At first I though naw its just that cyst and maybe it has more fluid in it. made a routine call to the Cancer Agency got voice mail... stated my concern and asked to have my oncologist call me or set up an appointment. Called again that same day. No response! About a week later it seemed bigger... Made a call again ( f-----g voice mail) with all the details and stated I was extremely concerned and I needed to speak with someone about it. no response again. I got busy and had to set my worries aside for a while. It was the beginning of july and I made another call stating it was urgent I get a sooner appointment with my Oncologist. No response!!!!! So around the 1st week of August I ranted on the phone and FINALLY got someone to call me back only to say they couldnt fit me in earlier and my best bet was to wait till my Aug 28 MRI... at this point its no longer a lump but a mass and in my heart I know its cancer. Had the MRI and as my Oncologist was on vacation they wouldnt give me the results. Now in the meantime I have found out my mom is being tested for an Ovarian mass and they were 90 % possitive (maybe more like 100% but couldnt say) that it was cancer. They even booked her chemo date before the results were in. I told her I would be there for her for her first chemo (she's a 3 hr flight away) and I was hoping my would end up being nothing..... So I got on the phone and harrassed every person I could to push the mri results through and have ANY doctor give me the results on the phone. I finally got to the right person (my oncologists personal secretary) and had her working on it. They pushed for the results and then I got the call. A Dr at the Cancer Agency called me late in the afternoon of Sept 2 They were sure it was cancer and they wanted to do a whole ton of tests immediately.  Sept 3rd I kept my appointment with my hairdresser as this was my first real hairstyle cut I had since my last Chemo A really cute layered bob that got ris of all the scraggy chemo curls. It made ME feel better & thats all that mattered. I would have nice hair for a month (maybe) Sept 4th Ultrasound guided core biopsy on the large tumor Sept 9th Full body CT scan Sept 10 Bloodwork saw my Oncologist,went over treatment (chemo, rads, then maybe surgery) went back to cancer agency to have a needle biopsy on a node or lump in my neck then straight to have my heart rythm tested. Sept 11 The needle biopsy the day before is cancer. I go for a full body bone scan. I phone over to my Oncs receptionist and asked if they had faxed in my port request yet (umm no) but chemo is tenatively booked for monday. I asked her to get it faxed immediately as I was going over to the pre op area for ports and was gonna get one come hell or high water. Went over there and explained my situation. The receptionist said no the earliest they could get me in was the END OF OCTOBER..... Ummm no, I need it today and I can wait all day if needed. She thought for a sec sat me in a chair and said wait right here Im making some calls. 5 minutes later she came running out asking if I had eaten today (no as I had the bone scan really early) She had found a vascular surgeon, 4 nurses and an operating room for right this minute. So I was signing the paperwork as I was stripping down for a lovely hospital gown and was rushed by wheelchair to the operating room for the port.. there was a few minor complications, I think they had to reset the tube/wire 3 times also I dont think they really gave the freezing time to set in as I could feel a lot of what they were doing (nothing like the last port I had) but whatever, Im thinking it might have been more difficult cause that side was radiated in 08. Had my son come to the hospital to drive me & my car home. My Oncologist calls me in the evening to tell me she had changed her mind on my chemo cocktail after consulting with many other Oncs online Sept 13, I start my Dexamethasone (2 pills 8am & 2 pills 8pm) So am now hopped up on steroids and will go for my first chemo 9am tomorrow. Sept 14 will be chemo 9am Sept 15 Mammo & ultrasound for markers (also my mums first chemo) Sept 18 Mugga scan So Now Ive vented DX so far is not all in yet.. so this is tenative Stage 3, ER weakly possitive (10%) PR negative and her2 equivical (all need retesting) Dont know tumor size yet, but mass in breast is about 1/3 of my breast (im a D) definately one node under arm and one above the colar bone in my neck So here I am again! Love & Hugs Suz Laugh your heart out, dance in the rain, cherish the memories & ignore the pain, love and learn, forget & forgive. Remember you only have one life to Live. Dx 11/25/2010, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, 8/23 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 10:51AM - edited Sep 16, 2009 10:52AM by suz45 Hi Alex, Yes this is a different cancer this time. At this point most of my results are in.. Ive had Aug 28, breast mri Sept 4, Ultrasound guided core biopst Sept 9, Full body ct scan Sept 10 Bloodwork, Onc visit, needle biopsy on the node just over my colarbone & heart rhythm scan Sept 11, Full body bone scan, port installed Sept 14, Ist chemo DC Sept 15,Full mammo and Ultrasound Sept 18, Mugga scan (not done yet) Last time around I had a lumpectomy with 21 nodes removed (2 possitive as one was attached to the tumor) Also I found out after the surgery that I carry the brca1 gene. Had I known this in advance Im sure I would have made a few different choices (lol Hindsight) I also had an oopherectomy in Sept 08 as that was one of the harder to detect cancers that I could get. My treatment then was 4 X AC & 4 X Paclitaxol every 2nd week, also gave myself neupogen shots for 6-7 days after each treatment, then rads and ooph From what I know so far this time around (the tests that were ready) is it has not spread to any of my organs (ct scan) Yesterday I got much more (unofficial) information. It is not one tumor in my breast its a cluster of 7-8 in the center top quarter of my breast, One has blood flow feeding it so thats the reason it spread so fast, underarm nodes one large and two small for sure, Then the neck, not sure how many exactly, but at least 2 - 4 again one has a blood flow so its another nasty one. Im on DC every three weeks for ?? 8 cycles, but my Onc said that may change once we have all this new info colaberated. Also still have to find out what my heart can take with mugga on friday. Needless to say this has been a whirlwind, but at least I understand what they are talking about this time around. I have an appointment already scheduled with a surgeon on Sept 28 but its just a consult as I have a bit of a long road in front of that, I also want reconstruction so we will talk to a plastic surgeon to see what those options are. At that point both my breasts will have been radiated and Ive heard its more difficult to do as the skin is not so good. But no matter I will fight on and do the best I can do and live each day as if its on purpose! Love & Hugs Suz

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 07:06PM - edited Apr 1, 2008 07:09PM by suz45 OK, Just got back from having port removed. So here's my play by play. I changed into a hospital gown (waist up) and went into the day surgery room. I had the same surgeon that placed the port originally. I layed on an operating table and they had me turn my head in the opposite direction of the port then placed a cloth so I wouldn't see. The worst part of the whole thing was the needles to numb the area. Once it was frozen I couldn't feel a thing. I could tell when they took the bulky end of the port out (not even remotely painful) and then they worked about 5 min removing the tube. Ive got dissolving stitches on the inside and tape on the outside. I haven't seen it yet as its bandaged but I think the incision is in the exact same place & size as the first one (about 1"). They didn't do anything with the scar on my collarbone. Overall it went really well, I didn't get any sort of meds to relax or calm me. I was nervous going in but honestly it really was no big deal and nothing like putting it in. Take care Suz ps, I had the port out exactly two weeks to the day from my last chemo. I think they like to wait three weeks.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 07:40PM - edited Dec 4, 2011 03:54AM by suz45 Hi Gals Im Suz, I first found out I had breast cancer in August 2007 and didn't find out I was BRCA1 until after I had had a lumpectomy with 21 nodes removed and had almost finished my AC/T chemo & 26 rads. I immediately had an oopherectomy and was told they would watch me carefully (hmmm) a year later I found a large lump in my other breast . It was a cluster of fast growing tumors so I went straight on another chemo Docetaxol, radiation then a bi-lateral MX. Oct, 2010 we found I had bone mets to my right 6th posterior rib. Thats when I posted here asking if this is where I belong now... lol, I got such a warm welcome from so many of you. I was fighting to try to get reconstruction and after months of begging, pleading and researching I won the fight! I was put on clodronate for the bone mets and was told I was NED! I think that was my last post here for a while. We had everything set up and ready to go when I found a lump at the base of my throat. It was a cluster of cancer in my nodes. We had to put my surgery on hold and I chose to go on to a trial drug Foretinib with the understanding I would be able to take a 2 week hiatus from it to get my recon. Well after a few months on this trial I had my second CT scan and it showed widespread Lymphadenopadhy throughout the trunk of my body including 2 small tumors attached to the pleural lining on the right side. My surgery got cancelled indefinitely... oh how I cried as I had fought so hard for it. As dumb as it may sound, as long as I had about 2 years left I wanted a pair of bumps so very badly. I took a break and went on vacation for a week in Sept this year knowing I was starting to have issues with fluid buildup under the left lung, I was planning on starting a new chemo as soon as I got back. We went to Las Vegas for a week so I could go on a helicopter ride through the Grand Canyon, then we landed right in the Canyon for a Champagne picnic with my darling DH, we flew back to Vegas as the sun was setting. Wow.... what an experience!! It was everything I had hoped it would be and more! This ride was #1 on my bucket list. By the time I got back home I was having breathing problems and they found that I had a litre of fluid in my right pleural. They drained it manually the first time, but within 2 weeks it was back so I had to have surgery to install a pleura X drain (sp). Nurses now come in to my home to drain it via vacuum bottles, as well as clean & change the waterproof dressings twice a week. Ive had it for 2 months now... I don't like it, but hopefully it will eventually dry out and I can get it removed (that's best case scenario) I had just found 2 perfect bikini tops this summer that I could wear with some pillow stuffing that looked great. Now if I wear them I have this huge bandage & tube right under the bra line. Funny how silly things like that can upset you more than the cancer :P Anyway I'm currently still taking the clodranate (for the bones) and have been on the oral chemo capecitabine. Its 4 pills twice a day for two weeks then one week off. I'm on my 4th cycle of it and find it extremely tolerable. I have my first CT scan on Dec 21.. I'm just guessing but I think this chemo is helping. My tumor markers have come down and I'm almost sure the tumors in my neck are smaller! The CT scan will be my actual proof... crossing my fingers! If for some reason I go off this chemo they have another one lined up for me, but its an IV drug (cant remember the name of it). I was actually given a choice of this or the oral one with the intention of utilizing the other once I finished with the first. I chose the oral chemo as it seemed like the side effects were easier and I wasn't into the whole IV thing all over again. Also didnt want to loose my hair for the 3rd time quite yet. With this one its thinned out but its hair. Ive just come back to the boards a few weeks ago... mostly reading and waiting for the right time to jump back in. I gotta say I feel like Ive come back home and finally have a safe place to fall if I need. Thank you Apple and everyone that has shared and posted here for opening the door. Well... that's my ride so far with a whole lot of short cuts (heh heh can you imagine if this was longer) Yes I talk too much once I get started   Much love & hugs! Suz

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 06:06PM suz45 wrote: Keepingon, If you have the time, energy and Dr's permission I would try Bikram Yoga (hot yoga) The pounds literally melted off and it left me feeling absolutely incredible. It felt very cleansing with the sweating and the way the postures are meant to naturally release the toxins in our bodies. It also grounds & centers you physically as well as emotionally. Its really hard to get through the first few sessions without bolting from the room, but they suggest lying down until you can join back in. I would leave there with my legs feeling like rubber and my mind clear & fresh. I also have anxiety and felt this helped it tremendously.  I gained about 40 pounds from tx. I started the Bikram Yoga at the urging of a longtime girlfriend, I had already gone through BC, lumpectomy, chemo, rads, oopherectomy, BC, chemo, rads, BMX and bone cancer when I started it (aprox 2 1/2 yrs tx) Ive also always been a very active bubbly, upbeat person. It seemed like nothing was helping me shed the pounds, puffed up feeling as well as feeling tight & painful everywhere. When I started Bikram along with my normal power walking the pounds started dropping off right away (Ive always eaten properly except when actually on chemo) I dont remember how long I did it for?? but sadly had to stop due to extremely high blood pressure when I went on the drug trial Foretenib. I would get back into it if I could but its impossible now with the Pleura drain and numerous other issues. I dont think I would last 10 minutes now and it would be dangerous at this point in my journey. Anyways that was definitely the one thing besides loss of appetite & nausea (currently from meds) that worked for dropping chemopause weight. I would suggest asking your oncologist if this is right for you as it really is HOT in the room, like a sauna. So its definitely not for everyone and individually were all dealing with different medical issues. Its also a very physical & mental workout. Good Luck, Hugs Suz

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 12:48AM suz45 wrote: Cheryl, Im another one that has fluid buildup in the pleura lining. As I understand it, the pleura is a lining thats normally attached to the lung. When the fluid builds up in the lining it compresses the lung which can be very painful & can also cause extreme fatigue as well as shortness of breath. Im not sure from your post if your Mom has fluid right in the lung or in the lining? Mine started the end of Sept 2011. I had it manually drained with a needle the first time (over a litre) and within a week it was right back again...thats enough fluid to reduce the lungs air capacity by half so the lung Onc set me up with a PleuraX drain. At first I had just over  800 cc's drained twice a week (over 1600 weekly) and at the same time I was started on the oral chemo Xeloda. The fluid is decreasing every week and today was my first full week with just one nurse visit/draining. I had only 360 cc's of fluid from the whole week!!! They are talking that I may be able to have it completely removed by Mar-April. The good thing about this type of drain is you dont have the bulbs or fluid on the outside of the body, just a clear plastic tube with a lock on the end. When the nurse comes to your home, she hooks it up to a vacuum bottle that slowly draws the fluid out. When done they sterilize, pad & bandage it all back up, then apply a waterproof dressing over it all. I have no issues with showers or shallow baths. They give me extra bandages just in case part of the tape lets go. Sorry for the long post... as you can see everyones situation/experience is a little different. Personally I dont like the drain but Im really glad I have it. The oncologist said that someone with my situation would have had almost no chance of the fluid drying up if they had done it by needle. Also they would have had me come in every 2nd week instead of getting a homcare nurse twice a week.... its much less painfull as it never gets really bad. Someone that has a larger volume of fluid can even have it done more frequently (3 x weekly or every 2nd day) Thats great because its not allowed to get really full = better breathing ,less pain. I hope this helps, Suz Oh and im triple neg with BRCA1

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 12:12AM suz45 wrote: Hi Wetcoast, It looks like you are on the same treatment that I am. I started a/c in December and will be starting taxol on Tues. My Oncologist said no problem when I asked to have a port put in. Where will you be getting your treatments? Mine are at the Vancouver Cancer Clinic. I copied out a few chemo bag supplies from another post. When I was having a/c it took about 1 1/2 hours so I really didnt need alot. I start Taxol on Tues and the Nurse said it will be 4-6 hours depending on how well I tolerate it. I used some of my chemo time to write out Christmas/Thank you & Birthday cards. I plan on bringing a small dvd player to watch a few movies during the longer treatments. Hope this helps. Chemo bag : pack it up and keep it packed so on chemo day, you just grab it. I replenished it night before. I brought my book, magazines, chocolate, hard sour lemon candy,pretzels , bottled (flavored) water or ice tea, my glasses and iPod, chapstick Your own blankie .... the hospital ones aren't as comfy. pics of your family ... Show the nurses your pics. You are a person and they need to know you and that you have a family who will wring their necks if they keep blowing your veins!!! Actually, you want them to take good care of you and give you good treatment!! old magazines: Have you noticed there are no current mags in the chemo clinic??? Bring your recently read People or latest paperback book and leave them so the person who forgot their reading material, or the first timers have something to read. Kleenex: Have you used their Kleenex??? It's that sandpaper tissue!! I like my real stuff, sometimes I love the lotioned up Kleenex. Take care, Suz

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 01:51AM suz45 wrote: Hi Donnalee, I used the lint roller constantly to get rid of the uncomfortable stubble. I post mostly Dec 07 gals. I am down to my last chemo coming up this next Tues. My treatment was 4 X AC every two weeks then 4 X taxol every two weeks. HAIR..... Its about the hair because hair is so personal. Head, I cut mine short then buzzed it when it started coming out in clumps after two weeks (christmas day) All other hair has been sporadic. Right now almost all hair is gone (7th treatment) My head has shedded twice and now I can just barely see fine white fuzz growing (full head) legs & armpits are smooth. 7 out of 8 tx. Eyebrows & eyelashes. This has been one of my biggest fears. My eyebrows are very thin and patchy, maybe they will hang in as they are, they really dont look so good. My eyelashes as of today are 100% gone. My eyelids are swollen and almost seem to have a thin blister along the upper edge. I did go out today and makeup really does hide looking sick.  If you have no lashes eyeliner (soft)totally hides it. I highly recommend the look good feel better class. They will teach you how to draw eyebrows and lashes. Also they utilize quality makeup, it really helps. I am almost done chemo and you will be too, really soon. I go on to radiation after this then I'm done . Please feel free to ask any questions. pm or here. Take care all & Im thinking about all of you. Warm hugs, Suz
